articles.title: Best of Sustainability In Your Ear: USEFULL’s Rob Kutner On Easing Reuse Adoption With Plastic Buy-Backs
articles.summary:
The scale of our plastic waste crisis is staggering: the U.S. alone uses over 100...
The post Best of Sustainability In Your Ear: USEFULL’s Rob Kutner On Easing Reuse Adoption With Plastic Buy-Backs appeared first on Earth911.
articles.content:
The scale of our plastic waste crisis is staggering: the U.S. alone uses over 100 million plastic utensils every day, most of which are used once and tossed into landfills where they’ll persist for centuries. From ocean pollution to overflowing campus dumpsters after lunch rush, single-use packaging defines modern food service—but universities and businesses are under mounting pressure to embrace sustainable alternatives. Tune in to a conversation with Rob Kutner, Chief Revenue Officer at USEFULL, which offers a practical solution to food service waste: a reusable takeout container system designed for the high-volume and fast pace of college cafeterias. USEFULL’s latest move challenges throwaway culture head-on with a plastic buyback program that pays institutional cafeterias to ditch disposables and go reusable.

The company has already made waves at universities like the University of Pittsburgh, Emory University, and the University of North Carolina Wilmington, achieving a remarkable 99% return rate for their containers. The economics are compelling. Rather than asking institutions to absorb the cost of switching to sustainable packaging, USEFULL creates financial incentives by purchasing a cafeteria’s existing plastic inventory, removing the sunk costs barrier and providing immediate value to cafeterias ready to make the transition. USEFULL built an ecosystem to improve the convenience of reuse, developing tracking systems, POS integration services, and local washing and inventory management to solve the campus reuse challenge. The timing couldn’t be better. As Bain & Company recently reported, ROI has become the driving force for growing adoption of sustainable practices. As companies recognize the threat to future business performance represented by the take-make-waste economic model, USEFULL demonstrates how simple steps, not grandiose plans for revolution, can create tractable, attractive, and profitable paths to reduced waste. You can learn more about USEFULL’s reusable packaging system and their expanding campus network at https://usefull.us/

Subscribe to Sustainability In Your Ear on iTunes

Follow Sustainability In Your Ear on Spreaker, iHeartRadio, or YouTube

Editor’s Note: This episode originally aired on April 11, 2025.
articles.reasoning: The article describes a practical and scalable solution to the plastic waste crisis through a reusable takeout container system with a plastic buyback program. This initiative has broad environmental benefits by reducing single-use plastic waste in institutional cafeterias, with demonstrated success at multiple universities and a high container return rate. The program also addresses economic barriers by financially incentivizing institutions to switch to sustainable packaging, making it a meaningful and impactful approach to sustainability.

articles.title: We must completely change the way we build homes to stay below 2°C
articles.summary: Construction generates between 10 and 20 per cent of the world's greenhouse gas emissions, but cities can slash their climate impact by designing buildings in a more efficient way
articles.content:
Construction generates between 10 and 20 per cent of the world's greenhouse gas emissions, but cities can slash their climate impact by designing buildings in a more efficient way

The Sawa residential building in Rotterdam, the Netherlands, is made from wood Hollandse Hoogte/Shutterstock

Cities must reduce greenhouse gas emissions from the construction of buildings and infrastructure by more than 90 per cent in the next two to four decades if the world is to avoid warming of more than 2°C. That means radical changes are needed in the design of buildings, or what they are built from, or both.

“Canada wants to triple its rate of housing construction. The US has a housing deficit, Australia has a housing deficit, [and so does] basically every country you go to right now,” says Shoshanna Saxe at the University of Toronto, Canada. “How do we build so much more while also demanding that we pollute so much less?”

Advertisement

Yet this is achievable, Saxe thinks. “We’re already building buildings that meet these targets; we just have to build more of the good and less of the bad,” she says. “We’ve had these skills and this knowledge for decades; we just have to use it.”

Globally, construction generates between 10 and 20 per cent of all greenhouse gas emissions, with much of that due to the production of cement. To get these emissions down, countries and cities need to know their current construction emissions and then plan how to reduce them in line with global targets.

But when Saxe’s team was asked to do this for the city of Toronto, the researchers were surprised to find that very few studies have attempted to estimate construction emissions on a city level.

Free newsletter Sign up to The Earth Edition Unmissable news about our planet, delivered straight to your inbox each month. Sign up to newsletter

“So we decided to come up with a way of getting a rough estimate of how much cities are emitting when they build buildings and infrastructure, and then also how much they could emit in the future to stay within climate limits,” says team member Keagan Rankin, also at the University of Toronto.

Rankin did this for 1033 cities by combining an existing model used to estimate the environmental impact of products over their lifetime – known as EXIOBASE – with data on the population and growth of cities, construction investment and employment, and so on. “This is all available datasets, but he put them together in new ways that we haven’t seen anybody do,” says Saxe.

Finally, the team estimated how fast each city would need to cut construction emissions to stay in line with the remaining global carbon budget for 2°C. These numbers are crucial for planning, Saxe says, “You need to know what the budget per sector is.”

Cities will bust these budgets if they meet housing demand by building single-family homes, the analysis suggests. They need to focus on more efficient multi-unit housing.

Using different materials such as wood or recycled concrete can also help reduce emissions, but better design is even more important, says Saxe.

“It’s very popular to say we’ll just build wood buildings and that solves it,” she says. “But wood also has greenhouse gas emissions. It is only zero emissions if you make all kinds of really optimistic assumptions, including the rate of forestry growth.”

“It’s actually much more effective to design your buildings well so there’s not a lot of wasted space, and wasted structure,” says Saxe.

Rankin says that cities are well positioned to take action. “Cities are very willing to implement climate action, and when it comes to construction, they have a lot of control,” he says. “It’s just, like we found with Toronto, a lot of cities don’t have the resources to go and determine a budget.”

“Without reducing emissions from the construction sector, we cannot meet the Paris Agreement, even if we reduce other emissions to zero,” says Prajal Pradhan at the University of Groningen in the Netherlands. “In my view, it is helpful to view emissions from a city budget perspective.”

It is also important to design buildings to be low-emission over their entire lifetime, not just during construction, says Susan Roaf at Heriot Watt University in the UK, such as by allowing natural ventilation. “We cannot go on developing cities as they have been growing, riddled with super-polluting ‘zombie buildings’,” she says.

Cutting construction emissions also involves prioritising what is built, Saxe says. For instance, Canada is still constructing a huge amount of oil and gas infrastructure. “We could build new housing for 10 million people [without increasing emissions] if we dialled back how much construction we were putting into oil and gas,” she says.
articles.reasoning: The article highlights a significant environmental challenge—construction emissions contributing 10-20% of global greenhouse gases—and presents actionable, research-backed solutions for cities worldwide to drastically reduce these emissions. It emphasizes the broad impact on global climate goals, the feasibility of change through better design and materials, and the importance of urban planning, offering hope and direction for meaningful climate action.
articles.personality_title: Cities can cut construction emissions by 90% to limit global warming
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Building homes and infrastructure causes 10 to 20 percent of the world’s greenhouse gas emissions. These emissions come mostly from making materials like cement. To keep global warming below 2°C, cities need to drastically reduce these emissions in the next 20 to 40 years.

**What happened** – Researchers at the University of Toronto studied how much cities around the world emit from construction. They combined data on city growth, construction spending, and jobs to estimate emissions for 1,033 cities. They found that many cities don’t measure construction emissions and lack plans to reduce them. The team showed that cities must build differently to meet climate goals, focusing on better design and materials.

**Impact** – This study is important because it gives cities a clear idea of how much they need to cut emissions from construction. It highlights that building more single-family homes uses more resources and creates more pollution. Instead, cities should build multi-unit housing and use materials like wood or recycled concrete carefully. Good design that avoids wasted space and materials is even more effective than just changing materials.

**What’s next step** – Cities can use these findings to create specific plans and budgets to lower construction emissions. They also need to prioritize what they build, for example by reducing construction for oil and gas infrastructure and focusing more on housing. Experts say cities have the power to act but need better tools and resources to plan.

**One-sentence takeaway** – By changing how and what they build, cities can cut construction emissions by over 90% and help keep global warming below 2°C.
articles.personality_title_fr: Les villes peuvent réduire de 90 % les émissions liées à la construction pour limiter le réchauffement climatique
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Construire des maisons et des infrastructures génère entre 10 et 20 % des émissions mondiales de gaz à effet de serre. Ces émissions proviennent principalement de la fabrication de matériaux comme le ciment. Pour limiter le réchauffement à moins de 2°C, les villes doivent réduire fortement ces émissions dans les 20 à 40 prochaines années.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Des chercheurs de l’Université de Toronto ont étudié les émissions liées à la construction dans 1 033 villes. Ils ont combiné des données sur la croissance des villes, les investissements en construction et l’emploi pour estimer ces émissions. Ils ont découvert que beaucoup de villes ne mesurent pas ces émissions et n’ont pas de plan pour les réduire. L’équipe montre que les villes doivent construire différemment pour respecter les objectifs climatiques, en améliorant la conception et les matériaux.

**Impact** – Cette étude est importante car elle donne aux villes une idée précise de la réduction nécessaire des émissions liées à la construction. Elle souligne que construire beaucoup de maisons individuelles utilise plus de ressources et pollue plus. Les villes devraient construire des logements collectifs et utiliser des matériaux comme le bois ou le béton recyclé avec précaution. Une bonne conception qui évite le gaspillage d’espace et de matériaux est encore plus efficace que de changer seulement les matériaux.

**Prochaine étape** – Les villes peuvent utiliser ces résultats pour créer des plans et des budgets précis afin de réduire les émissions liées à la construction. Elles doivent aussi prioriser ce qu’elles construisent, par exemple en réduisant la construction pour le secteur pétrolier et gazier et en se concentrant davantage sur le logement. Les experts disent que les villes ont le pouvoir d’agir mais manquent d’outils et de ressources pour planifier.

**Résumé en une phrase** – En changeant leurs méthodes et leurs choix de construction, les villes peuvent réduire de plus de 90 % les émissions liées à la construction et aider à limiter le réchauffement à moins de 2°C.
articles.personality_title_es: Las ciudades pueden reducir en un 90 % las emisiones de construcción para limitar el calentamiento global
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Construir casas e infraestructuras genera entre el 10 y el 20 % de las emisiones mundiales de gases de efecto invernadero. Estas emisiones provienen principalmente de la producción de materiales como el cemento. Para mantener el calentamiento global por debajo de 2°C, las ciudades deben reducir estas emisiones en las próximas dos a cuatro décadas.

**Qué pasó** – Investigadores de la Universidad de Toronto estudiaron las emisiones de construcción en 1,033 ciudades combinando datos sobre crecimiento urbano, inversión en construcción y empleo. Descubrieron que muchas ciudades no miden estas emisiones ni tienen planes para reducirlas. El equipo mostró que las ciudades deben construir de manera diferente para cumplir con los objetivos climáticos, mejorando el diseño y los materiales.

**Impacto** – Este estudio es importante porque ofrece a las ciudades una idea clara de cuánto deben reducir las emisiones de construcción. Destaca que construir muchas casas unifamiliares usa más recursos y genera más contaminación. En cambio, las ciudades deberían construir viviendas multifamiliares y usar materiales como la madera o el concreto reciclado con cuidado. Un buen diseño que evite espacios y materiales desperdiciados es aún más efectivo que solo cambiar los materiales.

**Próximo paso** – Las ciudades pueden usar estos resultados para crear planes y presupuestos específicos para bajar las emisiones de construcción. También deben priorizar qué construyen, por ejemplo, reduciendo la construcción de infraestructuras de petróleo y gas y enfocándose más en viviendas. Los expertos dicen que las ciudades tienen el poder de actuar, pero necesitan mejores herramientas y recursos para planificar.

**Resumen en una frase** – Cambiando cómo y qué construyen, las ciudades pueden reducir las emisiones de construcción en más del 90 % y ayudar a mantener el calentamiento global por debajo de 2°C.

articles.title: Renewables accounted for 47.5% of electricity sources in the EU and 65.8% in Portugal in 2024
articles.summary: In Portugal, 65.8% of the electricity consumed in 2024 was produced from renewable sources, mainly hydro and wind, a share above the 47.5% EU average
articles.content:
LUXEMBOURG – Almost half (47.5%) of the electricity consumed in 2024 in the European Union (EU) came from renewable sources, with Portugal in fourth place with 65.8%, according to data released today by Eurostat.

According to data from the EU’s statistical service, in 2024 renewable sources accounted for 47.5% of the bloc’s gross electricity consumption, an increase of 2.1 percentage points (pp) compared with 2023.

Eurostat highlights that this figure has almost tripled (30 pp) since the start of the time series in 2004, further reporting that the share stood at 15.9% in 2004, rose to 28.6% in 2014 and jumped to 47.5% in 2024.

Wind power (38.0% of the total) and hydropower (26.4%) accounted for almost two-thirds of the total electricity generated from renewable sources.

They were followed by solar energy, with a contribution of 23.4%, while solid biofuels and other renewable sources accounted for 5.8% and 6.4%, respectively.

Among the Member States, Austria recorded a 90.1% share of electricity consumption from renewable sources, mainly hydroelectric.

Sweden (88.1%, mainly hydroelectric and wind), Denmark (79.7%, mainly wind) and Portugal (65.8%, mainly hydro and wind) are the other countries with the highest share.

At the opposite end of the table – all with shares of renewable sources lower than 25% – are Malta (10.7%), Czech Republic (17.9%), Luxembourg (20.5%), Hungary and Cyprus (24.1% each) and Slovakia (24.9%). (14/01/26)
articles.reasoning: The article reports a significant and measurable increase in renewable energy usage across the EU, with Portugal and several other countries achieving high shares of electricity from renewables. This represents meaningful progress in climate action and sustainable energy, benefiting society broadly by reducing reliance on fossil fuels and contributing to environmental conservation.
articles.personality_title: Portugal leads EU with 65.8% renewable electricity in 2024

**Context** – In 2024, many European countries increased their use of renewable energy sources like wind, water, and solar power to produce electricity. The European Union (EU) tracks how much electricity comes from these cleaner sources to understand progress in energy and climate goals.

**What happened** – The EU reported that 47.5% of its electricity in 2024 came from renewable sources, up from 45.4% in 2023. Portugal stood out by producing 65.8% of its electricity from renewables, mostly from hydroelectric (water) and wind power. Portugal ranked fourth among EU countries, behind Austria, Sweden, and Denmark, which also have very high shares of renewable electricity.

**Impact** – This shows a big shift away from fossil fuels toward cleaner energy in Europe. Portugal’s high renewable share means less pollution and a smaller carbon footprint from electricity use. It also highlights how countries with access to natural resources like rivers and wind can use them to power homes and businesses sustainably.

**What's next step** – Countries are likely to continue investing in renewable energy technologies and infrastructure to increase these shares even more. This will help the EU meet climate targets and reduce dependence on imported fuels.

**One-sentence takeaway** – In 2024, Portugal and the EU made strong progress in using renewable energy, with Portugal producing nearly two-thirds of its electricity from clean sources like wind and water.

articles.title: Bulgaria will participate as a host country under the Financial Mechanism for Renewable Energy
articles.summary: In the three coal regions of the country, projects for ground-mounted photovoltaic plants with battery storage systems will be financed
articles.content:
In the three coal regions of the country, projects for ground-mounted photovoltaic plants with battery storage systems will be financed

SOFIA – Bulgaria will participate as a host country under the Financial Mechanism for Renewable Energy, decided the Bulgarian caretaker government in connection with an invitation sent to the country by the Directorate-General for Energy of the European Commission to declare binding interest for 2026.

The EC plans to announce a procedure under the Financial Mechanism through which investment support will be provided for projects implemented on the territory of Bulgaria and Finland as host countries. The financial resource is provided by Luxembourg, and the total budget under the procedure is 55 million euros.

Projects for ground-mounted photovoltaic plants with battery storage systems in Bulgaria and those for ground-mounted photovoltaic systems in Finland will be financed.

In Bulgaria, the projects will be in the three coal regions – Pernik, Kyustendil and Stara Zagora, and the facilities must operate for at least 15 years after their commissioning.

The management of the procedure – the announcement of the call, the collection and evaluation of project proposals and the monitoring of their implementation – will be carried out by the European Climate, Infrastructure and Environment Executive Agency. Public or private legal entities from any country in the world may apply for funding.

Bulgaria’s participation in the Financial Mechanism as a host country will provide investment support for combined projects for the construction of photovoltaic plants with energy storage systems, which will make it possible to increase the installed capacities using solar energy and to increase the consumption of environmentally friendly energy in the country. The territorial location of the projects in the three coal regions of the country will complement the financial instruments applied under the territorial just transition plans and will support the energy transition of these regions, the government press service said in a statement. (14.01.2026)
articles.reasoning: The article reports a significant investment in renewable energy projects in Bulgaria's coal regions, promoting energy transition and environmental sustainability with broad societal benefits. It provides clear details about the funding mechanism, project scope, and expected impact, fulfilling the criteria for inspiring good news.
articles.personality_title: Bulgaria to host solar energy projects in coal regions with EU support
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Bulgaria has long depended on coal for energy, but the country is now working to use more renewable sources like solar power. The European Commission invited Bulgaria to join a special funding program to support clean energy projects.

**What happened** – Bulgaria agreed to participate as a host country in the Financial Mechanism for Renewable Energy, a program backed by the European Commission and funded by Luxembourg. This program will provide 55 million euros to support solar power projects with battery storage in Bulgaria’s three coal regions: Pernik, Kyustendil, and Stara Zagora. These projects must run for at least 15 years.

**Impact** – This funding will help build new solar power plants combined with batteries to store energy. It will increase the use of clean solar energy in areas that have relied on coal, supporting a smoother change to greener energy. The projects also complement other efforts to help these regions shift their economies away from coal.

articles.personality_title_es: Bulgaria acogerá proyectos solares en regiones mineras con apoyo de la UE

Estos proyectos deben operar al menos 15 años.
